titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Bathed and walk’d this morning, though the weather was somewhat cold. Went into Boston. visits to T. Amory. J. Wells, Mrs: Otis the mother, and her daughter in law. Attended the sale of an house in school-street. (Mr: Freeman’s) Call’d at Mr: Smith’s, and agreed to purchase his house. That which formerly belonged to Dr: Welsh, and in which I lived with him— The price 6000 dollars.— Dined with Daniel Sargent junr: and a company of twelve of our old friends, chiefly belonging to the Saturday’s club. Otis. both T. Amory’s. F. Amory, Hall, Cooper, Lowell, T. H. Perkins, Frazier, & Callender. It was past 6 o’clock, before I could get away— Took out Mrs: Foster and her child with me to Quincy. Stop’d at Gardner’s to leave him a letter.

2. Made up my account for the department of State— Dr: Tufts, Mr: Smith of Boston, my aunt Smith, Mr: & Mrs: Foster, and W. Shaw dined with us— The funeral of Mr: Quincy was from my father’s house. The company was very numerous— After returning, his Will was read to the relations, but I was not present. Mrs: Tufts first informed me, that he has thought fit to leave me a legacy of 500 dollars, for which I ought to feel properly grateful, as it was quite unexpected to me— My uncle Adams pass’d the evening with us: having returned this afternoon from an ordination at Barnstable.

3. Long walk this morning; but did not bathe— Went to Roxbury and dined with Thomas Amory; the one I had not known before I went to Europe— The company was nearly the same, with that I met at Sargent’s the other day. Sent Whitcomb into Boston; he call’d for me in the Evening, and I return’d to Quincy— Weather cloudy, and extremely dark.

4. Long walk in the morning; and bathed. Went to meeting both parts of the day. Heard Mr: Williams of Weymouth— He dined with us— In the afternoon, began to arrange some of the papers my father gave me yesterday— Spent part of the evening at my uncle Adams’s.— Mr: Black & his Lady, and Mrs: Blake at my fathers when I came home.

5. Walk before breakfast down to mount Wollaston— Went to Boston with Mr: Daniel Greenleaf. Visits to judge Sullivan, Dr: Welsh, Mrs: Green (Mr: Copley’s daughter), and to Mr: Storer’s; Call’d at Mr: Smith’s— Dined at Mr: Foster— Met in the afternoon T. Thomas of Newbury-Port— Return’d to Quincy with Mr: Greenleaf, at about 8 in the Evening.— Walk before dinner with Hall, & visit to Miss Breck—

6. Long walk before breakfast— Round by Gulliver’s brook— Bathed at 10 o’clock, it being then high water. My mother went to Weymouth and spent the day— I went over to Captain Beale’s, an hour, this evening.— He this day returned from his journey to Taunton— My uncle Adams here.

7. Went to Boston this morning with Mrs: Cranch— Called on Doctor Welsh; settled with him and took his note upon interest— At the union bank & received my dividend— At Mr: Smith’s; took his deed in fee of the house in Hanover street, and drew a set of three bills of exchange, in his favour upon Messrs: Bird, Savage and Bird, for £1400 sterling— Dined at Mr: Allen the Sheriff’s with a company of ladies and gentlemen— Judge Sullivan & his lady, Mr: & Mrs: Andrews and Miss Breck, Mr: & Mrs: Stoughton, (formerly Mrs: Deneuville), Mr: & Mrs: Elliot, Mr: & Mrs: Morton, and Mr H. Brimmer, with some others. Mr: Boylston particularly— I return’d with Mrs: Cranch to Quincy in the Evening.

8. Employed most of this day in sorting and arranging papers— Wrote letters in the afternoon. Bathed at noon, with the high tide— The weather is cold, but I find yet no inconvenience from bathing— Captn: Beale spent part of the evening with us.

9. Walk before breakfast— Bathed at 1. o’clock. Walk’d with my father to Mount Ararat, after dinner. He wrote to Messrs: Willink of Amsterdam, authorising me to manage his affairs in Holland— Several ladies of the neighbourhood took tea with my mother— Mrs: Cranch had a letter from her son, at Washington 26. Septr:— My wife & family then well.— Wrote in the Evening to my brother— Found this morning the document he wanted.

10. Went to Boston this morning alone— Left my deed from Mr: Smith at the register’s office to be recorded. Asked Mr: Cooper to leave the bench of the common pleas, which he did— Left at his office twenty 4 per cent bonds with four coupons to each, and two 5 per cent bonds to be recorded— Called at the loan office, and afterwards at the branch bank, where I received 12 dollars for quarterly dividend upon 8 pr: ct: stock— Paid Mr: B. Hall 100 dollars for the two last assessments on five shares of the Middlesex Canal—agreed to purchase two more shares at 75 pr: ct:— Received several letters at the post office— Delivered to Mr: Smith two copies of my letter of advice to Messrs: Bird, Savage & Bird— Called on Mr: Parsons; he was out— And on Mrs: G. Green— On Miss Breck to invite her out to Quincy; but she was out of town— Dined with Mr: Otis— Mr: & Mrs: Erskine— Mr: & Mrs: Mifflin and Miss Bond, Mr: & Mrs: Morton, Mr: & Mrs: Howard, Mr: & Mrs: T. Amory, Mr: W. Sullivan, and others were the company.— Went out to Quincy in the Evening, and took up Mr: Shaw, at Mr: Gurley’s, in Dorchester.

11. Went to meeting in the forenoon and heard Mr: Whitney. My Aunt Smith, and Mr: & Mrs: Bass (Nancy Adams) dined with us— Slip’d the time of meeting after dinner.— T. Welsh, came up from Boston— In the Evening pass’d an hour at Mr: Black’s. Mr: & Mrs: Greenleaf were there. Young Beale & his sister here in the evening.— I am endeavouring to arrange the papers of my father respecting his property in the hands of Messrs: Willink.

12. Went into Boston this morning with William Shaw.— Saw Mr: Foster, and requested him to attend the auction for me to-morrow— Saw Mr: Cleland, and employed him to sell me a bill of exchange for £500— Could not finish this business.— Dr: Morse introduced me to Dr: Dwight, President of Yale college— Called on Mr: Parsons, but he was not at home— Dined at Mr: Smith’s—Mrs: Smith unwell— Engaged a seat for Thursday morning, in the mail stage for New-York.— Called at Mr: Storer’s, and offered my services to the ladies there, if they go on the same day.— Came out of Boston early in the afternoon, and spent an hour with Mr: Gardner at Milton.
13. From 7 this morning, untill 9 at night, I was employed without more than an hour’s interval, in writing letters, drawing out an account with Messrs: Willink and making a copy of the whole.

14. After writing a letter or two, I set out this morning upon my progress to Washington, to bring home my wife. The morning being rainy I went into Boston in the carriage, and took Whitcomb with me— Met Mr: Jackson, Dr: Welsh and Mr: Gardner, going out to Quincy.— Upon arriving in town, Received from Mr: Cooper, the bonds and coupons for interest, which he has recorded— Mr: Smith took of me a bill upon Bird, Savage and Bird for £200 sterling, for which he is to account with me— Dined at Mr: Jackson’s—Dr: Welsh and Mr: Gardner were there— Called after dinner upon Mrs: Shaw— In the evening went with Mr: Smith, to the Wednesday evening club, of which I was formerly a member.— There were several visitors—Dr: Smith, the President of Princeton college—Mr: Andrews of Newbury-Port, and Mr: Bancroft of Worcester— At 9 went home with Mr: Smith and lodg’d at his house.

15. Called upon Mrs: Shaw this morning and took her letters for her family. At ten o’clock took passage in the stage, which was well fill’d, by Genl: Mattoon, my old classmate Fiske—Mr: Judd, Mr: Tappan, Mr: Edwards, all persons belonging to our western Counties—and one or two others— We dined at Sudbury, and reached Worcester, between 7 and 8 in the evening.— Here Mr: Fiske left us; this being the place of his residence— We prevailed upon our driver to go as far as Brookfield, twenty miles beyond Worcester, where the stage usually stops— We did not arrive till half past one in the morning.— Four of us had only two beds, in one chamber to lodge in.

16. We left Brookfield at 8 this morning; and all my fellow passengers, excepting Mr: Judd, soon parted from me, to take the Northampton road— He went no further than Springfield; where another gentleman, a Mr: Green, from the Natchez, took his place— We got to Hartford at about 6 in the evening.

17. Instead of Mr: Green, I had this morning, a student of Yale-College, as my only companion from Hartford. We took our departure between two and three o’clock and breakfasted at Wallingford, which by the new turnpike road is half way to New-Haven. By this road the distance is shortened about five miles between the two Cities— We took in here a young woman who went as far as New-Haven, where I was again deserted by my fellow-travellers— In their stead however, I found a new company sufficient to crowd the stage as full as possible— Among the new comers were a french gentleman, Mr: Dureste, with two ladies, sisters, Madame La Roche and Madame,nieces of Mr: Madey of Martinique, an old acquaintance of mine— And Mr: Swift of Alexandria, whom I knew in London, in the year 1784— We dined at Strafford, and came on at night as far as Stanford— I had travell’d 85 miles in the course of the day. We got in between 9 and 10 at night.

18. Of the four hours we had to sleep, I could scarcely enjoy the advantage of two, being in the same chamber with two other passengers, one of whom neither rested nor allowed us to rest— Before three in the morning we started again— Breakfasted at Rye in the State of New-York, and between noon and one o’clock reached the Hobuck ferry, just without the bounds of the city— The yellow-fever being in New-York, and the intercourse between it and Philadelphia being interdicted, we who are obliged to pass through Philadelphia, found ourselves under a necessity of avoiding to go within the line of New-York. The wind being fair down the river, we engaged the ferrymen to take us in their boat, directly to Elizabeth-Town, where in little more than two hours they landed us. We found at the landing a light carriage just ready to start, and went in it to Lyon’s tavern, where we stop’d for the night— Here we parted from our french fellow travellers.

19. Between two and three this morning we left Elizabeth-town, with a new stage load of fellow travellers. Mr: Swift alone of the old company continued the route with me— In the new set, were two brothers by the name of Pearce; originally from Concord in Massachusetts, but settled for many years past in the Mississippi territory; and just arrived from it, by the way of New-Orleans— We breakfasted at Brunswick, and dined at Bristol in Pennsylvania. At the Washington tavern, about seven miles short of Philadelphia, we were detained by the health officer, and obliged to walk about a mile to the house of Elisha Gordon a Justice of the peace, to make affidavit before him and receive from him a certificate that we had not been within fifteen days in the city of New-York. Mr: Gordon would receive nothing for the certificate, but it detained us two hours more than was necessary— For a magistrate qualified to administer oaths, on the spot of detention, with printed blank certificates might do the same business in five minutes— Mr: Swift however had pass’d through New-York, on his way to Boston, the 7th: of this month, and therefore could not proceed with us— A Spanish Gentleman, from New-York yesterday, was likewise detained. The rest of us having obtained our certificates, continued our journey, and arrived at Philadelphia, in the evening between 8 and 9.— From the George tavern where the stage stop’d, I went immediately with Mr: Swift’s certificate to the house of Mr: Commages, President of the board of health; and not finding him at home, to the board of health itself, sitting at the health-office in the State-house yard— Upon the certificate and a representation of circumstances, they immediately granted a permission to Mr: Swift, to come into the city.— I then went to Mrs: Roberts’s in Walnut-street, and bespoke my lodgings, intending to stay in Philadelphia to-morrow, to wait for Mr: Swift, who I supposed would not get here soon enough to proceed in the stage for Baltimore in the morning. I next called at my brother’s lodgings at Mr: Rutter’s, but found he had been out of town, since Saturday.— I then return’d to the George-tavern, gave the permission for Mr: Swift to the landlord, with a request that he would immediately send it out by an express, and took my baggage to Mrs: Robert’s— My brother soon after came in, from Burlington, and pass’d an hour with me; soon after 10 I retired much fatigued, to bed.

20. At 7 this morning, Mr: Swift came into my bed chamber before I had risen; told me that he had received the certificate so soon last night, as to have been enabled to reach the city between one and two o’clock this morning. That upon enquiry he found the mail-stage for Baltimore would set off at 8 this morning; had engaged a seat in it for himself, and one for me, if I chose to go— I therefore immediately arose— Call’d at my brothers lodgings to inform him of my determination to depart, took an hasty breakfast, and went to join the stage at the office but miss’d it— Return’d to Mrs: Roberts’s and found at her door the stage waiting for me— By this delay it was almost 9 in the morning before we left Philadelphia— We came through Chester, and Wilmington to Newport, where we dined— Then continued our route to Elkton and the Susquehannah; at 9 in the evening we cross’d the ferry, and supp’d at Havre de Grace— The stage is generally full, and we had several changes of passengers—none of the old stock remaining but Mr: Swift and myself— We rode the whole night through.

21. At 6 o’clock this morning we arrived at Baltimore, and breakfasted at Evans’s tavern (Indian Queen) At 8 we took the mail stage for Washington, with a new stock of passengers, besides Mr: Swift and me. We overtook another stage, whose driver held a race with ours, at the risk of life or limb to all the passengers in both carriages— We got safely through it however, and I arrived at Mr: Johnson’s house in the city of Washington at four in the afternoon— The distance from Philadelphia to Baltimore is 104 miles; and from Baltimore to this city, about 46— I had the happiness to find my wife and child, as well as the rest of Mr: Johnson’s family, in good health— They had company in the evening; but I found myself so much fatigued that I went to bed almost immediately after my arrival.

22. Found myself entirely refreshed this morning with a good night’s rest.— After breakfast I went with Mr: Johnson, and paid visits—to the President, (Mr: Jefferson), to Mr: Madison, Secretary of State, Mr: Gallatin, Secretary of the treasury, Mr: Smith, secretary of the navy, and Mr: Dearborn, secretary at war—to Mr: Dalton, and Mr: Cranch; also to Mr: and Mrs: Hellen.— Saw the President, and Mr: Gallatin— The other Gentlemen were not at home— We saw however Mrs: Madison, Mrs: Dalton, and Mrs: Hellen, whom we took with us upon our return— They dined with Mr: Johnson, whose whole family was thus assembled together— Mrs: Hellen went out in the afternoon, with Mrs: A— They soon return’d however and we all spent the evening together.

23. Mr: Cranch and Mr: White called upon me this morning, and I took a ride on horseback with them to the bridge, locks, canal, and little falls upon the Potowmack, about five miles from the city.— We return’d at about two o’clock— Mr: T. Petre, who married one of the grand-daughters of Mrs: Washington and lives next door to Mr: Johnson’s called to pay me a visit— Mr: Johnson was very ill and confined the whole day to his bed.

24. Mr: Stoddert, late Secretary of the navy, and Mr: F. Deakins came to see me, and I return’d Mr: Petre’s visit— Went to the Secretary of State’s office, and saw Mr: Madison, with a view to settle my account: he referred me to the Treasury department, where by a late and judicious arrangement all accounts are to be settled— I went there and delivered to the Auditor all my accounts, from the year 1794 to the close of my public service, but am apprehensive he will require more than the time that will suit me to audit them.— Mr: Gallatin is unwell, and was not at the office— Dined at Mr: Cranch’s, with Mr: Dalton, Mr: White, Mr: Deblois and Mr: T. Johnson— Mr: Cranch has four children, two sons & two daughters, one of the latter not yet a month old— We walk’d home in the evening— The distance is about 4 miles.

25. Mr: T. Cook, a nephew of Mr: Johnson, who resides in George-town called to see me— I returned the visits of Mr Stoddert and Mr: Deakins— T. Johnson and myself dined at Mr: Dalton’s, with Mr: Cranch and Mrs: Deblois Dr: May— Mr: Deblois and Miss Dalton, with Mr: & Mrs: White were gone to Mount-Vernon— Took up Mrs: Adams, at her sisters, as we return’d home— Mr: Johnson is getting better.

26. Mr: Johnson gave me some of his papers to look over.— He has been unfortunate in his trusts, and considered as a prey by every man with whom he has dealt— I am strongly apprehensive of the issue of his principal causes now depending.— Went to the treasury-office, and found Mr: Gallatin the Secretary there— The Auditor was not at his office— I received the warrants for the transfer of my 8 per Ct: stock from the books at Philadelphia, to those at Boston— But I found myself charged not only for the 3000 guilders upon Van Berkel’s bill, but for the 20,000 dollars, I drew in December 1796, for the payment of the Antwerp interest. De Wolf’s account in which it is credited, they say was destroyed by the fire— I have so far explained both the transactions that the Secretary assured me the charges would no longer remain upon me but as a matter of form, untill the accounts of the bankers at Amsterdam, and of Mr: De Wolf should authorize a regular credit to me.— Dined at the President’s— Besides Mr: Johnson’s family, Mr: & Mrs: Madison, Miss Payne, and Mr: Lewis, the President’s secretary, form’d the company.— The dinner, as Mrs: Orby Hunter said, was of chilling frigidity— We spent the evening and supp’d at Mr: Hellen’s.

27. Went this morning with Mrs: Johnson, Kitty, Mrs: Adams, the child and Epps, to Mount-Vernon to visit Mrs: Washington— Mr: Johnson intended to have gone with us, but just before setting out received a letter which required his immediate departure for Annapolis— At half past nine in the morning we left the City and cross’d the ferry at George-town— In two hours we reached Alexandria, where we staid about half an hour, and then proceeding arrived at Mount-Vernon soon after three— Here we dined and spent the rest of the day— Mrs: Washington has with her, Mr: & Mrs: Lewis with their two children, Miss Henley, Miss Maria Washington, and Mr: Washington Custis, her grandson & brother to Mrs: Lewis— This lady, whom I formerly saw at Philadelphia, before her marriage, is a very pleasing and beautiful woman.

28. We slept at Mount-Vernon, and this morning just before ten, took leave and return’d to Washington. We stop’d at Alexandria as before, and at half past three got to Mr: Johnson’s door— The distance is about 18 miles and Alexandria is half way between the two places. The views along the Potowmack are very beautiful, as are the prospects from Mount-Vernon— We found Mrs: Hellen with her child at Mr: Johnson’s— Her husband is gone with him to Annapolis— Mr: & Mrs: Pichon, called to pay us a visit in the evening.

29. Mr: Harrison the Auditor called on me this morning.— I went to the treasury, to make such explanations to him as might be necessary for auditing my accounts, and find myself once more charged with about twenty-four thousand dollars more than I ought to account for.— This arises from various sources, and requires various explanations from me, vouched with documents which I am now not able to furnish— The points to be elucidated are these.

1. Mr: Randolph, Secretary of State at the time of my appointment to the Hague, has charged me with a payment of 4500 dollars on the 12th: of July 1794. vouched by my receipt of that date for that sum. In fact I never received from him more than 3100 dollars— I gave him the rect: upon his supplying me with the latter sum at Philadelphia, and a credit upon the bankers at Amsterdam: from whom I was to receive, and actually have received the rest.

2. I am twice charged with a sum of fifty guineas, which I received in London, by an order of Mr: Jay, upon Messrs: Cazenove— As I wished not to have this sum appear at all in Mr: Jay’s accounts, I desired Messrs: Willink & van Staphorst, to repay the money to Messrs: Cazenove, and charge the amount to me— They have accordingly made the charge— But Messrs: Cazenove did nevertheless charge it in their acct: with Mr: Jay.

3. Messrs: Bird, Savage and Bird, have charged me with a debit of £300 sterling June 23. 1797. and a credit of £22:5. Augt: 8. same year, upon the fund provided for M. La Fayette— This was only the repayment to me of a sum I had sent to Madame de la Fayette at her urgent request March 16. 1795.

4. The same house have charged me for the payment of salary for my self and my secretary for two years; viz, from July 1798 to July 1800. Although they never made me any such payment— I had a letter of credit upon them, and they charged the amount as paid, every quarter-day, although in fact I never drew.

I had some conversation upon these points with the Secretary of the Treasury, and with the Secretary of State, there will probably be no difficulty in coming eventually to a settlement, upon all excepting the first— I fear that either the United States or myself will have nothing better than a claim upon Mr: Randolph for 1400 dollars of that— Called upon Dr: Thornton, but he was not at home.— We dined very late expecting Mr: Johnson’s return home— He did not however come— In the evening, went with Mrs: Adams & her brother to George-town; where we called upon Mrs: Cooke, a sister of Mr: Johnson’s; and upon her son.— I spent the Evening chiefly in looking over Mr: Johnson’s papers.

30. Spent most of this forenoon, at the Offices of the Secretary of State, and of the Auditor Mr: Harrison— Mr: Gallatin not being at his office I went with T. Johnson, to find him at his house, but met him on the way; and returned with him to the Auditor’s Office— Conversed with all these persons upon the points of my Account which remain open. I found at the Secretary of State’s office a document much to my purpose respecting the first point— It is the letter from Mr: Randolph to the bankers of the United States at Amsterdam 7. Augt: 1794. containing an order upon them to pay me 1400 dollars besides my annual salary and that of my secretary.— It is further observable that the charge against me of 4500 dollars received from Mr: Randolph, is not made by Mr: Randolph himself, but by his successor Mr: Pickering; not at the time of the transaction in 1794. but in April 1800. Mr: Johnson and Mr: Hellen return’d this day from Annapolis; they reached home just before dinner time— I went over to the Bank at Georgetown, but found it shut— Mr: Meredith, late treasurer of the United States spent the evening with us at Mr: Johnson’s.— Mrs: Adams severely ill with a cold, which obliges me to postpone our journey from to-morrow, untill Tuesday.

31. I went over to the bank of Columbia at Georgetown and exchanged a bill of 100 dollars for specie— They had no small bills of other banks to give me, as I should have preferred instead of dollars— I called again at the Offices of the Secretary of State, and of the Auditor, to ask for copies of my receipt to Mr: Randolph, dated 12. July. 1794, and of his order to the bankers of the United States at Amsterdam, to pay me 1400 dollars in addition to my salary. Mr: Madison assured me that he was perfectly satisfied with regard to the mode of the transaction, but the auditor who upon the single voucher of my rect: has given credit to Mr: Randolph in settling his accts: and has not charged him with the 1400 dollars, for which he gave me the order on the bankers at Amsterdam, continues to make
make difficulties, and I question whether he will allow my charges as I state them, if he can possibly help it.— T. Johnson went with me to look over the Capitol— We saw the Representative and Senate chambers, and went up on the top of the building from which there is an extensive and pleasant prospect— We dined in a family party at Mr: Hellen’s— Came home early in the evening. My wife’s cold, a little better.
Day. Nothing regular through the month.
